Legal_Issue: Whether the citizenship judge correctly applied the Koo factors to assess residency under s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Willoughby was absent from Canada for 745 days during the four-year period and maintained a home in Australia
Remedy_Requested: Minister appealed the approval of Willoughby's citizenship application
Court_Ruling: Appeal allowed; citizenship judge's decision set aside
Defendant_Behavior: Prolonged absence from Canada, dual residence in Australia
Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to meet statutory residency requirements
Assessment_Factor: Koo factors for qualitative assessment of residency
Evidence_Used: Record of absences, evidence of home in Australia
Application_Basis: Accumulation of three years of physical residence in Canada within four years prior to application
Evidence_Assessed: Duration of absences, ties to Canada, maintenance of foreign residence
Governing_Rule: Koo test for assessing residency when statutory days are not met
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient analysis of absences and attachment to Canada by citizenship judge
Outcome: Federal Court found decision unreasonable and overturned it
Decisional_Body: Citizenship Commission (via citizenship judge), reviewed by Federal Court
Harm_Assessment: Risk of granting citizenship to individual not meeting residency obligations
Cause_Description: Extensive absences and dual residences undermined compliance with residency requirements
Evidence_Handling: Federal Court found inadequate consideration of key evidence by lower decision-maker
Evidence_Issues: Lack of detailed analysis of residency patterns and connections to Canada
Residency_Compliance: Not satisfied due to excessive absences
Evidence_Assessment: Qualitative evaluation of residency using Koo factors required but inadequately performed
Decision_Rationale: Citizenship judge failed to properly apply Koo factors; decision was unreasonable
Evidentiary_Issues: Incomplete analysis of applicantâ€™s residential ties and absences
